Egypt is indeed an odd pairing here.

While China has internal issues, I see none that could potentially be destabilizing or that could take it off the course it is on now. India has a lot of deep social issues to get resolve, the least of which may be poverty, before it can spring ahead and surpass China. If India doesn't solve its gender gap, catastrophe and unrest will ensue.

I agree with Kevin that Iran is one to watch. Egypt is also one to watch for another change in leadership. Should the Iranian people decide to unseat the mullahs and should that coincide with peace in the Middle East, then the big competition to unlock great potential will be between it and Palestine.

I respectfully disagree. If colleges were to admit men with lower grades and test scores than women, we would be seeing scores of lawsuits. At this point, it would be impossilbe, the girls are so far ahead.

You say in the higher grades it is a choice to boys to excel. I would suggest that by this point they have disengaged so much that they no longer know how to engage. How are they suddently supposed to develop the confidence and maturity necessary to make positive choices for themselves? We are talking about teens at this point, some of whom are mature enough to not act out-generally girls- because they don't want to mess up their future. The majority of teens lack that maturity.

You clearly don't know how easy it can be to disengage. As one who was disengaged as a young child due to the circumstances of my life, I can only say it is easy, inevitable even. Were it not for an exceptional teacher, I may never have engaged.

"Organic" is by no means the same as "pure," whatever that is. Dangerous compounds are found in nature. Pure onions will kill your dog. Many varieties of mushroom will kill people.

Designer label lipsticks are up to $40 now, by the way. I draw the line at $35, but inflation may push the price higher. We've all known there's little to no difference in products for decades. We still buy the expensive stuff.
We could adopt the precaution principle, as most other Western countries do.

I'm not sure where you got the idea that Avon is "pure." They use parabens and other questionable ingredients, and most of their products rank on the EWG database as about the same toxicity as most other brands.

I have nothing against Avon, but unless you have information I don't, they aren't any better or worse than most mainstream brands.

Oh, boy, Mark, you picked a really thorny subject.

Imagine a world in which corporations were responsible to the citizenry. A place where what we eat and drink is always organic and pure, what we use is organic and untainted, and that we are able to celebrate all life (human and otherwise) equally. A utopian existence indeed!

Anita Roddick, creator of the Body Shop, said it well years ago in her book. All cosmetics are pretty much the same except for the advertising and packaging. Want to pay $22.50 for a lipstick by Lancome instead of $1.99 for one by Brucci? Go ahead! Avon products are some of the purest made and the cheapest. Expensive or not, what you are purchasing might be pretty much the same in both brands. Could be good for you or toxic, but you won't know unless you go research it for yourself.

The FDA like the FAA is charged with conflicting duties -- keep things safe but promote the industry simultaneously. Can't happen. If and when our society ever really cares about staying healthy, safe, kind and conscious, we will find ourselves in a completely new world, unrecognizable by today's standards. The FDA would finally be able to protect us but we wouldn't need protection and wouldn't that be great?

Thanks, as always for a great column.

Dave, "The government, by bringing the civil fraud charges under a 1989 law created after the savings and loan crisis"
Clearly the basis for which they are bringing this suit. And I think like many others here I feel that there should be laws passed to make this type of fraud criminal, since time in jail is probably the only deterrent to such criminal behavior (which really is stealing when you get down to it), stemming from nothing but greed. People got rich, defrauding and stealing from investors.

Dave, your comparison to just buying a bad investment is insulting. Their job was to rate these investments and they gave high ratings to what they very well knew was basically junk, certainly at the very least they were very risky investments, and I think evidence will show that. They put market considerations over truth in ratings, as was pointed out by their own executive, and as a result defrauded countless investors. This was not simply that they didn't see a collapse coming, and like everyone else were caught off guard. They didn't need to know a collapse was coming, they knew the investments were risky and they overrated them to get more business, that's fraud.

It does seem odd that we have a for-profit rating business that we blindly trust to tell us all what things are worth, and yet they have their own motivations in giving ratings, not the least of which is to keep customers happy, the very customers who are trying to hock us risky investments.

It's interesting that you don't describe the crimes your cousin was convicted of -- murdering her four children, aged 4, 6, 7, and 14, in an act of vengeance against her ex-husband.

I'm against the death penalty, but it takes a special kind of chutzpah to plead for someone as having no living relatives when she's the one who killed our of them.

According to the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, 3,146 people were on the nation's death rows as of last Oct. 1, and only 63 or 2 percent were women.

One of those women is my cousin Susan D. Eubanks in the CCWF at Chowchilla, CA. While Susie is guilty of her horrific crime her family has never wanted her to be killed by the state of California. We have been firmly on the side of life in prison and an end to the death penalty nationwide.

I testifed during the penalty phase of her trial asking the jury to spare Susie's life and, in the alternative, give her life in prison. It is extremely difficult to have a relative on death row especially a female relative we have seen mature and change.

At her trial Susie had no living parents are grandparents to plead for her life. Her mother died when Susie was only 8 years old. Her late father and grandparents who she lived with were alcoholics. One brother and sister are now deceased. She has only 1 living brother left in her immediate family and he offers little support. We remain hopeful that either California or the U.S. Supreme Court will stop capital punishment some day. I am thankful Susie is still alive today and pray that she will remain alive for many years to come. Reading about progress in another state gives us a dim glimmer of hope for our Susie.

"Some will be hurt unfortunately. They will adjust and life will go on."

I can only hope some of that hurt lands on you, and we can all watch as you adjust to your new life.
How about just cutting the price gouging contracts?

My "adjusting" means that my household will have to learn to make do with one week of pay less per month due to the planned furloughs if there is no agreement. Nice that other people feel like I have to just adjust MY life when their income will be completely unaffected.

Regarding overpaid gov't employees, my husband is a civilian engineer who makes significantly LESS working for the DoD than he would make in the private sector, but wants to continue to serve his country now that he is no longer in the Reserves. Maybe some employees are overpaid, but many are NOT. I understand cuts may (and should) be made within the DoD and elsewhere in the gov't, but wouldn't it be better to do deliberate, targeted cuts, rather than hasty across-the-board slashes in spending?

And lastly, I'm not sure why austerity would work here when it hasn't worked ANYWHERE else in the world. Why go for a solution that has been proven not to work? Aren't we innovative and smart enough in this country to figure out a new solution that might have a chance of actually improving the economy?

My two cents. Let me give it before the penny is no longer in circulation.

We are not broke. We overspend. This started many years ago.

Why should I pay 50% of my income so that the government can overpay an employee to do something that any person should be, could be, and would be willing to do for less?

I believe that we can get the same products and government services if the budget were cut by 25% or more.

Right now, if you earned $400,000 you will give the federal, state, and local governments $200,000. That is insane.

I read earlier today the Navy's plan for when the sequester happens. It seems like a great plan that will not do a lot of damage. Some will be hurt unfortunately. They will adjust and life will go on. I have not seen the other government agencies plans for the sequester. They should start working on a plan.

Highways do not have to cost as much as they do now. The cost of highways are that expensive because they believe there is no limit to the amount of money they can get from the government. Airplanes, tanks, tires, etc. are all being price gouged.
